newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sets plan to eliminate 50 tons of plutonium.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sets plan to eliminate 50 tons of plutonium.

text.p: The Energy Department on Monday announced it plans to get rid of 50 tons of plutonium left over from the nuclear weapons programme by immobilizing some in glass and burning the rest in nuclear power plants.
The department also said it will store nuclear weapons materials at three sites, down from the current seven sites.

"Today's actions will reduce global nuclear danger," Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary said in a statement released at a news conference on the issue. "For five decades, the United States built up a huge stockpile of plutonium -- the deadly stuff of nuclear weapons. Today, we begin to destroy it."
"We have a clear message to the world: we are committed to irreversible nuclear reductions and we will ensure that surplus plutonium is never again used for nuclear weapons," O'Leary said.
Nuclear arms control activists have criticised the approach of burning plutonium in commercial nuclear energy reactors, saying it would perpetuate commercial use and production of plutonium.
But the Energy Department said that, under its policy, the plutonium used in reactors would not be re-processed to recover plutonium.
